She was the best teacher they ever had, a master good teacher; fitted a boy for Bowdoin College all except his Greek, that last season before she was laid aside from sickness. She took right holt to bear it the best she could, and begun to study on what kind o' things she could do. First she used to make out to knit, a-layin' there, for the store, but her hands got crippled up with the rest of her; 't is the wust kind o' rheumatics there is. She had me go round to the neighborin' schools and say that if any of the child'n was backward an' slow with their lessons to send 'em up to her. utterance: "I ought to tell you the stories of some old silver that I keep in that cupboard; if I were to die, nobody would know anything about them."
speaker: Tom Burton's grandmother

utterance: "Do you mean the old French spoons, and the prince's porringer, and those things?"
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "What a charming old bit!"
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "Where in the world did it come from? English, of course; and it looks like a loving-cup. A copy of some old Oxford thing, perhaps; only they didn't copy much then. I should think it had been made for a child."
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "Here's an inscription, too, but very much worn."
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "Put it down a minute,"
speaker: Tom Burton's grandmother

utterance: "Every time I have thought of it I have been more and more ashamed to have it in the house. People were n't so shocked by such things at first; they would only be sentimental about the ruined homes, and say that, 'after all, it was the fortune of war.' That cup was stolen."
speaker: Tom Burton's grandmother

utterance: "But who stole it?"
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "Your father brought it here,"
speaker: Tom Burton's grandmother

utterance: "My son, Tom Burton, your father, brought it home from the war. I think his plan was to keep it safe to send back to the owners. But he left it with your mother when he was ordered suddenly to the front; he was only at home four days, and the day after he got back to camp was the day he was killed, poor boy"
speaker: Tom Burton's grandmother

utterance: "I remember something about it now,"
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "I remember my mother's talking about the breaking up of Southern homes, and all that; she never believed it until she saw the cup, and I thought it was awfully silly. I was at the age when I could have blown our own house to pieces just for the sake of the racket."
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "And that terrible year your grandfather's and your mother's death followed, and I was left alone with you two of us out of the five that had made my - home'"
speaker: Tom Burton's grandmother

utterance: "I should say one and a half,"
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "What a boy I was for a grandson! Thank Heaven, there comes a time when we are all the same age! We are jolly together now, aren't we? Come, dear old lady, don't let's think too much of what's gone by;"
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "I want you to take that silver cup back, Tom,"
speaker: Tom Burton's grandmother

utterance: "Go back and finish your coffee."
speaker: Tom Burton's grandmother

utterance: "How in the world am I going to take it back?"
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "Do you really know just where it came from? And then it was several years ago."
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "Your grandfather knew; they were Vir- ginia people, of course, and happened to be old friends; one of the younger men was his own classmate. He knew the crest and motto at once, but there were two or three branches of the family, none of them, so far as he knew, living anywhere near where your father was in camp. Poor Tom said that there was a beautiful old house sacked and burnt, and everything scattered that was saved. He happened to hear a soldier from another regiment talking about it, and saw him tossing this cup about, and bought it from him with all the money he happened to have in his pockets."
speaker: Tom Burton's grandmother

utterance: "Then he did n't really steal it himself!"
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "No, no, Tom!"
speaker: Tom Burton's grandmother

utterance: "Only you see that it really is a stolen thing, and I have had it all this time under my roof. For a long time it was packed away with your father's war relics, those things that I could n't bear to see. And then I would think of it only at night after I had once seen it, and forget to ask any one else while you were away, or wait for you to come. Oh, I have no excuse. I have been very careless, but here it has been all the time. I wish you would find out about the people; there must be some one belonging to them- some friend, per- haps, to whom we could give it. This is one of the things that I wish to have done, and to forget. Just take it back, or write some letters first: you will know what to do. I should like to have the people under- stand."
speaker: Tom Burton's grandmother

utterance: "I'll see about it at once,"
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "I believe you could n't have spoken at a better time. I have been thinking of going down to Virginia this very week. I hear that they are in a hurry with fitting out that new scientific expedi- tion in Washington that I declined to join, and they want me to come on and talk over things before they are off. One of the men is a Virginian, an awfully good fellow; and then there's Clendennin, my old chum, who's in Washington, too, just now; they 'll give me my directions; they know all Vir- ginia between them. I'll take the cup along, and run down from Washington for a few days, and perhaps get some shooting."
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "How pretty this old chasing is round the edge, and the set of the little handles! Oh, here's the motto! What a dear old thing, and enormously old! See here, under the crest,"
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "Je vous en prie Bel-ami."
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "Yes, it is charming, as you say. But I only wish to return it to its owners, Tom."
speaker: Tom Burton's grandmother

utterance: "Je vous en prie Bel-ami."
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "I remember that your grandfather said it belonged to the Bellamys,"
speaker: Tom Burton's grandmother

utterance: "Of course: how could I forget that? I have never looked at it properly since the day I first saw it. It is a charm- ing motto-they were very charming and distinguished people. I suppose this is a pretty way of saying that they could not live without their friends. I beg of you, Bel- ami; it is a quaint fancy; one might turn it in two or three pretty ways."
speaker: Tom Burton's grandmother

utterance: "Or they may have meant that they only looked to themselves for what they wanted, Je vous en prie Bellamy!"
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "All right; I think that I shall start to-morrow or next day. If you have no special plans,"
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "Do go, my dear; you may get some shooting, as you say,"
speaker: Tom Burton's grandmother

utterance: "You've started me off on a fine ro- mantic adventure,"
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: "Come; my cigar's gone out, and it never was good for much; let's go in and try the cards, and talk about things; perhaps you'll think of something more about the Bellamys. You said that my grandfather had a classmate'"-
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: Mos' thar now, Cun'l. See them busted trees pas' thar, an' chimblies? You tu'n down nax' turn; ride smart piece yet, an' you come right front of ol' Mars Bell'my's house. See, he comin' 'long de road now. Yas, 'tis Mars Bell'my shore, an' 's gun.
speaker: a negro boy

utterance: Yas, sir; that 's Mars Bell'my, sir.
speaker: a negro boy

utterance: I was on my way to call upon you, Colonel Bellamy; my name is Burton.
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: Will you come with me to the house?
speaker: Colonel Bellamy

utterance: I have been charged with an errand of friendship. I believe that you and my grandfather were at Harvard together.
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: I see the resemblance to your grandfather, sir. I bid you welcome to Fairford. Your visit is a great kindness.
speaker: Colonel Bellamy

utterance: This was formerly the billiard-room. Your grandfather would have kept many memories of it. Will you go in, Mr. Burton?
speaker: Colonel Bellamy

utterance: I am sorry to have the inconvenience of deafness. Will you tell me again the name of our guest?'
speaker: Madam Bellamy

utterance: He is my old classmate Burton's grandson, of Boston.
speaker: Colonel Bellamy

utterance: I remember Mr. Burton, your grandfather, very well. He was your guest here the autumn before we were married, my dear; a fine rider, I remember, and a charming gentleman. He was much entertained by one of our hunts. I also saw that you carried a gun. My dear, did you bring home any birds?
speaker: Madam Bellamy

utterance: I had scarcely time, or perhaps I had not my usual good fortune. The birds have followed the grain-fields away from Virginia, we sometimes think.
speaker: Colonel Bellamy

utterance: I can offer you a partridge. I shot one as I rode along. I am afraid that I stopped Colonel Bellamy just as he was going out.
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: I thank you very much. And you will take supper with us, certainly. You will give us the pleasure of a visit? I regret very much my granddaughter's absence, but it permits me to offer you her room, which happens to be vacant.
speaker: Madam Bellamy

utterance: No, no. You must certainly stay the night with us; we shall make you most welcome. It will give my husband great pleasure; he will have many questions to ask you.
speaker: Madam Bellamy

utterance: This is something which I have come to restore to you, sir. I believe that it is your property.
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: I ask no questions; it was the fortune of war. This cup was my grandfather's, my father's, and mine; all my own children drank from it in turn; they are all gone before me. We always called it our lucky cup. I fear that it has come back too late
speaker: Colonel Bellamy

utterance: Je vous en prie Bel-ami.
speaker: Colonel Bellamy

utterance: Shall we move our chairs before the fire, Mr. Burton? My dear wife is but frail. She sees me companioned for the evening, and is glad to seek her room early; if you were not here she would insist upon our game of cards. I do not allow myself to dwell upon the past, and I have no wish for gay company; My daily dread in life is to be separated from her.
speaker: Colonel Bellamy

utterance: Be still, all of you! Your mistress is still asleep. Go round to Milton, and he will attend to you. I'll come presently.
speaker: Colonel Bellamy

utterance: You will observe this iron-work, sir. My grandfather had the pattern carefully planned in Charleston, where such work was formerly well done by Frenchmen.
speaker: Colonel Bellamy

utterance: I think you bring good fortune. Nothing can make me so happy as to have my husband find a little pleasure.
speaker: Madam Bellamy

utterance: Madam Bellamy, the portrait; is it like any one? is it like your granddaughter? Could I have seen her on my way here?
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: Yes, my granddaughter would have been on her way to Whitfields. She has always been thought extremely like the picture: it is her great-grandmother. Good-by; pray let us see you at Fairford again;
speaker: Madam Bellamy

utterance: Je vous en prie, Belle amie,
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: You have been most welcome. I beg that you will be so kind as to repeat this visit. I shall hope that we may have some shooting together.
speaker: Colonel Bellamy

utterance: I shall hope so too.
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: Your grandfather would have done this, sir. I loved him, and I take it from you both. My own gun is too poor a thing to offer in return.
speaker: Colonel Bellamy

utterance: I wish that I might be like a son to you. May I write, sometimes, and may I really come to Fairford again?
speaker: Tom Burton

utterance: Oh yes; we must think of the Christmas hunt.
speaker: Colonel Bellamy

utterance: I had to do my last row mostly by feel-in'. I'm proper glad I pushed through, an' went back an' ended off after supper. 'T would have taken me a good part o' to-morrow mornin', an' broke my day.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: T ain't no use for ye to work yourself all to pieces, John. I declare it does seem harder than ever that we could n't have kep' our boy; he'd been comin' fourteen years old this fall, most a grown man, and he'd work right 'longside of ye now the whole time.
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: T was hard to lose him; I do seem to miss little John. I expect there was reasons why 't was best. I feel able an' smart to work; my father was a girt strong man, an' a monstrous worker afore me. T ain't that; but I was thinkin' by myself to-day what a sight o' company the boy would ha' been. You know, small's he was, how I could trust to leave him any- wheres with the team, and how he'd be- seech to go with me wherever I was goin'; always right in my tracks I used to tell 'em. Poor little John, for all he was so young he had a great deal o' judgment; he'd ha' made a likely man.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: But then there's the little girls, a sight o' help an' company. Katy, she's most as good as a boy, except that she ain't very rugged. She's a real little farmer, she's helped me a sight this spring; an' you've got Susan Ellen, that makes a complete little housekeeper for ye as far as she's learnt. I don't see but we 're better off than most folks, each on us having a work- mate.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: That's so, John.
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: Where be the little girls so late? 'Tis gettin' long past eight o'clock. I don't know when we've all set up so late, but it's so kind o' summer-like an' pleasant. Why, where be they gone?
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: I've told ye; only over to Becker's folks. I don't see myself what keeps 'em so late; they be- seeched me after supper till I let 'em go. They're all in a dazzle with the new teacher; she asked 'em to come over. They say she's unusual smart with 'rethmetic, bu
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: Let her take her comfort. Them things draws her to the teacher, an' makes them acquainted. Katy's shy with new folks, more so 'n Susan Ellen, who's of the business kind. Katy's shy-feelin' and wishful.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: I don't know but she is. Ain't it sing'lar how well acquainted you be with that one, an' I with Susan Ellen? 'Twas always so from the first. I'm doubtful sometimes our Katy ain't one that 'll be like to get married- anyways not about here. She lives right with herself, but Susan Ellen ain't nothin' when she's alone, she's always after com- pany; all the boys is waitin' on her a'ready. I ain't afraid but she 'll take her pick when the time comes. I expect to see Susan Ellen well settled, she feels grown up now, but Katy don't care one mite 'bout none o' 101 them things. She wants to be rovin' out o' doors. I do believe she'd stand an' hark to a bird the whole forenoon.'
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: Perhaps she 'll grow up to be a teacher. She takes to her book more 'n the other one. I should like one on 'em to be a teacher same 's my mother was. They're good girls as anybody 's got.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: So they be.
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: Be you sound asleep, John?
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: I don't know but what I was a'most. I should laugh if I was to fall sound asleep right here on the step; 't is the bright night, I expect, makes my eyes feel heavy, an' 't is so peaceful. I was up an' dressed a little past four an' out to work. Well, well!
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: Where's the little girls? I'd better step along an' meet 'em.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: I wouldn't just yet; they'll get home all right, but 't is late for 'em certain. I don't want 'em keepin' Mis' Becker's folks up neither. There, le''s wait a few min- utes,
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: I've be'n a-thinkin' all day I'd like to give the child'n some kind of a treat. I hur- ried up my work 'cause I had it so in mind. They don't have the opportunities some do, an' I want 'em to know the world, an' not stay right here on the farm like a couple o' bushes.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: They're a sight better off not to be so full o' notions as some is.
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: Certain; but they 're good, bright child'n, an' commencin' to take a sight o' notice. I want 'em to have all we can give 'em. I want 'em to see how other folks does things.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: Why, so do I,”—here the rocking-chair stopped ominously, "but so long's they're contented"-
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: Contented ain't all in this world; hop- per-toads may have that quality an' spend all their time a-blinkin'. I don't know 's bein' contented is all there is to look for in a child. Ambition 's somethin' to me.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: Now you 've got your mind on to some plot or other.
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: Why can't you talk right out?
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: 'T ain't nothin' special. Well there, you do find things out the master! I only thought perhaps I'd take 'em to-morrow, an' go off some- where if 't was a good day. I've been promisin' for a good while I'd take 'em to Topham Corners; they 've never been there since they was very small.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: I believe you want a good time yourself. You ain't never got over bein' a boy.
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: There, go if you want to an' take 'em; they've get their summer hats an' new dresses. I don't know o' nothin' that stands in the way. I should sense it better if there was a circus or anythin' to go to. Why don't you wait an' let the girls pick 'em some strawberries or nice ros'berries, and then they could take an' sell 'em to the stores?
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: I should like to get me some good yellow-turnip seed to plant late. I ain't more 'n satisfied with what I've been gettin' o' late years o' Ira Speed. An' I'm goin' to provide me with a good hoe; mine 's gettin' wore out an' all shackly. I can't seem to fix it good.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: Them's excuses. You just cover up the hoe with somethin', if you get it-I would. Ira Speed's so jealous he 'll remember it of you this twenty year, your goin' an' buyin' a new hoe o' anybody but him.
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: I've always thought 't was a free coun- try. I don't want to vex Ira neither; he favors us all he can in trade. 'Tis difficult for him to spare a cent, but he's as honest as daylight.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: Wa'n't it dark gittin' home through the woods this time o' night?
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: I don't love to have you gone so late; mother an' me was timid about ye, and you 've kep' Mis' Becker's folks up, I ex- pect. I don't want to have it said that my little girls ain't got good manners.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: The teacher had a party. Goin' home from school she asked the Grover boys, an' Mary an' Sarah Speed. An' Mis' Becker was real pleasant to us: she passed round some cake, an' handed us sap sugar on one of her best plates, an' we played games an' sung some pieces too. Mis' Becker thought we did real well. I can pick out most of a tune on the cabi- net organ; teacher says she 'll give me lessons.
speaker: Susan Ellen
addressee: John Hilton and John Hilton's wife

utterance: I want to know, dear!
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: Yes, an' we played Copenhagen, an' took sides spellin', an' Katy beat everybody spellin' there was there.
speaker: Susan Ellen
addressee: John Hilton and John Hilton's wife

utterance: Ain't you got nothin' to tell, daugh- ter?
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: Tell 'em what's goin' to be the last day o' school, and about our trimmin' the school- house,
speaker: Katy

utterance: 'T will be a great time. I don't see why folks wants to go trapesin' off to strange places when such things is happenin' right about 'em.
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: Ain't we goin', father?
speaker: Susan Ellen

utterance: Yes, sister, we're goin' certain', an' goin' to have a great time too. You go an' help mother about breakfast an' them things; we want to get off quick 's we can. You coax mother now, both on ye, an' see if she won't go with us.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: She said she would n't be hired to. She says it's goin' to be hot, an' she's laid out to go over an' see how her aunt Tamsen Brooks is this afternoon.
speaker: Susan Ellen

utterance: Remember an' lay off your shawls when you get there, an' carry them over your arms. They 'll do to keep the dust off your new dresses goin' an' comin'. An' when you eat your dinners don't get spots on you, an' don't point at folks as you ride by, an' stare, or they'll know you come from the country. An' John, you call into Cousin Ad'line Marlow's an' see how they all be, an' tell her I ex- pect her over certain to stop awhile before hayin'. It always eases her phthisic to git up here on the high land, an' I 've got a new notion about doin' over her best-room car- pet sence I see her that 'll save rippin' one breadth. An' don't come home all wore out; an', John, don't you go an' buy me no kickshaws to fetch home. I ain't a child, an' you ain't got no money to waste. I expect you'll go, like 's not, an' buy you some kind of a foolish boy's hat; do look
speaker: John Hilton's wife
addressee: John Hilton, Susan Ellen, and Katy

utterance: Yes, yes, hold on!
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: I wish you was goin' too. I do so!
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: They're nothin' but a pack o' child'n to- gether,
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: Yes, sister, we're goin' certain', an' goin' to have a great time too.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: I guess we're as good as they be,
speaker: Susan Ellen

utterance: Now sit up straight and appear pretty. We're among the best people now, an' I want folks to think well of you.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: Good-morning, Mr. Hilton. I am very glad to see you, sir;
speaker: Judge Masterson

utterance: These are your daughters, I am sure. How she recalls your mother! I am glad to see this dear child. You must come to see me with your father, my dear. Bring both the little girls, and let them run about the old garden; the cherries are just getting ripe. Perhaps you will have time to stop this afternoon as you go home?
speaker: Judge Masterson
addressee: John Hilton, Susan Ellen, and Katy

utterance: I should call it a great pleasure if you would come and see us again some time. You may be driving our way, sir,
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: Not very often in these days. I thank you for the kind invitation. I should like to see the fine view again from your hill westward. Can I serve you in any way while you are in town? Good-by, my little friends!
speaker: Judge Masterson
addressee: John Hilton, Susan Ellen, and Katy

utterance: It was worth comin' twice as far
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: Now I've got to do my errands, and we can let the horse rest and feed. I'll slip his headstall right off, an' put on his halter. I'm goin' to buy him a real good treat o' oats. First we'll go an' buy me my straw hat; I feel as if this one looked a little past to wear in Top- ham. We'll buy the things we want, an' then we'll walk all along the street, so you can look in the windows an' see the han’- some things, same 's your mother likes to. What was it mother told you about your shawls?
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: To take 'em off an' carry 'em over our arms,
speaker: Susan Ellen

utterance: She was talkin' about wantin' a new pepper-box, one day; the top o' the old one won't stay on. Can't we have some candy, father?
speaker: Susan Ellen

utterance: Yes, ma'am. I feel as if some would be good myself. What's all this?
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: I'm goin' to have our pictures taken; 't will please your mother more 'n a little.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: There, what did make you wear your shawls? You ain't been an' wore 'em all day long? I wanted folks to see how pretty your new dresses was, if I did make 'em. Well, well! I wish more 'n ever now I'd gone an' seen to ye!
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: An' here's the pepper-box!
speaker: Katy

utterance: That really is what I call beautiful. Our other one was only tin. I never did look so high as a chiny one with flowers, but I can get us another any time for every day. That's a proper hat, as good as you could have got, John. Where's your new hoe?
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: I declare to Moses if I did n't forget all about it. That an' my yellow turnip seed, too; they went clean out o' my head, there was so many other things to think of. But 't ain't no sort o' matter; I can get a hoe just as well to Ira Speed's.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: You an' the little girls have had a great time. They was full o' wonder to me about everything, and I expect they 'll talk about it for a week. I guess we was right about havin' 'em see somethin' more o' the world.
speaker: John Hilton's wife

utterance: Yes, we did have a beautiful day. I didn't expect so much. They looked as nice as anybody, and appeared so modest an' pretty. The little girls will remember it perhaps by an' by. I guess they won't never forget this day they had 'long o' father.
speaker: John Hilton

utterance: How be you to-day? Why, what a sight o' flowers, Mis' Bickford! What be you goin' to do with 'em all?
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: My sister's boy fetched 'em over. You know my sister Parsons's a great hand to raise flowers, an' this boy takes after her.. He said his mother thought the gardin never looked handsomer, and she picked me these to send over. They was sendin' a team to Westbury for some fertilizer to put on the land, an' he come with the men, an' stopped to eat his dinner 'long o' me. He's been growin' fast, and looks peaked. I expect sister 'Liza thought the ride, this pleasant day, would do him good. 'Liza sent word for me to come over and pass some days next week, but it ain't so that I can.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Why, it's a pretty time of year to go off and make a little visit
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: I ain't got my sitting-room chamber carpet taken up yet. I do feel condemned. I might have done it to-day, but 't was all at end when I saw Tommy coming. There, he's a likely boy, an' so relished his dinner; I happened to be well prepared. I don't know but he's my favorite o' that family. Only I've been sittin' here thinkin', since he went, an' I can't remember that I ever was so belated with my spring cleaning.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: 'T was owin' to the weather. None of us could be so smart as common this year, not even the lazy ones that always get one room done the first o' March, and brag of it to others' shame, and then never let on when they do the rest.
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: Why, I do declare if you haven't got a rose in bloom yourself! Ain't it a lovely rose? Why, Mis' Bickford!
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: Yes 'm, it's out to-day. I'm glad you come in so as to see it.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Goin' to make up all your flowers into bo'quets? I think the short-stemmed kinds is often pretty in a dish.
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: I thought I should make them into three bo'quets. I wish there wa'n't quite so many. Sister Eliza 's very lavish with her flowers; she's always been a kind sister, too.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: I expect you 're going to carry 'em over to the burying-ground?
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: Yes 'm. You see I was goin' over to my brother's folks to-morrow in South Fairfield, to pass the day; they said they were goin' to send over to-morrow to leave a wagon at the blacksmith's, and they'd hitch that to their best chaise, so I could ride back very comfortable. You know I have to avoid bein' out in the mornin' sun?
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance:
So I thought 't was a good opportunity to just stop an' see if the lot was in good order, last spring Mr. Wallis's stone hove with the frost: an' so I could take these flowers. She gave a sigh. I ain't one that can bear flowers in a close room,
――
they bring on a headache; but I enjoy 'em as much as anybody to look at, only you never know what to put 'em in. If I could be out in the mornin' sun, as some do, and keep flowers in the house, I should have me a gardin, certain,
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: A garden 's a sight o' care, but I don't begrudge none o' the care I give to mine. I have to scant on flowers so 's to make room for pole beans. A few flowers gives me just as much pleasure as more would. You get acquainted with things when you've only got one or two roots. My sweet-williams is just like folks.
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: Mr. Bickford was partial to sweet-williams. I never knew him to take notice of no other sort of flow- ers. When we'd be over to Eliza's, he'd walk down her gardin, an' he 'd never make no comments until he come to them, and then he'd say, 'Those is sweet-williams.' How many times I've heard him!
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Those is sweet-williams.
speaker: Mr. Bickford

utterance: You ought to have a sprig of 'em for his bo'quet.
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: Yes, I've put a sprig in.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: I don't know but you think it's foolish to tie 'em up this afternoon. I thought I could put 'em in a bucket o' water out in the shed, where there's a draught o' air, and then I should have all my time in the morning. I shall have a good deal to do before I go. I always sweep the setting-room and front entry Wednesdays. I want to leave everything nice, goin' away for all day so. So I meant to get the flowers out o' the way this afternoon. Why, it's most half past four, ain't it? But I sha'n't pick the rose till mornin'; 't will be blowed out better then.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: The rose? Why, are you goin' to pick that, too?
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: Yes, I be. I never like to let 'em fade on the bush. There, that 's just what's a-troublin' me. I don't seem to know which of 'em ought to have it. I do so hate to make a choice between 'em; they all had their good points, especially Mr. Bickford, and I respected 'em all. I don't know but what I think of one on 'em 'most as much as I do of the other.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Why, 't is difficult for you, ain't it? I don't know 's I can offer advice.
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: No, I s'pose not. I feel sure you would if you could, Abby.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: There's one thing, they're all in a better world now. they can't feel such little things or take note o' slights same 's we can.
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: No; I suppose 't is myself that wants to be just. I feel under obligations to my last husband when I look about and see how comfortable he left me. Poor Mr. Wallis had his great pro- jects, an' perhaps if he 'd lived longer he 'd have made a record; but when he died he 'd failed all up, owing to that patent corn- sheller he'd put everything into, and, as you know, I had to get along 'most any way I could for the next few years. Life was very disappointing with Mr. Wallis, but he meant well, an' used to be an amiable person to dwell with, until his temper got spoilt mak- in' so many hopes an' havin' 'em turn out failures. He had consider'ble of an air, an' dressed very handsome when I was first acquainted with him, Mr. Wallis did. I don't know's you ever knew Mr. Wallis in his prime?
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: He died the year I moved over here from North Denfield. I just knew him by sight. I was to his funeral. You know you lived in what we call the Wells house then, and I felt it would n't be an intrusion, we was such near neighbors. The first time I ever was in your house was just before that, when he was sick, an' Mary 'Becca Wade an' I called to see if there was anything we could do.
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: They used to say about town that Mr. Wallis went to an' fro like a mail-coach an' brought nothin' to pass. He ought to have had a better chance than he did in this little neighborhood. You see, he had ex- cellent ideas, but he never 'd learned the machinist's trade, and there was somethin' the matter with every model he contrived. I used to be real narrow-minded when he talked about moving 'way up to Lowell, or some o' them places; I hated to think of leaving my folks; and now I see that I never done right by him. His ideas was good. I know once he was on a jury, and there was a man stopping to the tavern where he was, near the court house, a man that traveled for a firm to Lowell; and they engaged in talk, an' Mr. Wallis let out some o' his notions an' contrivances, an' he said that man would n't hardly stop to eat, he was so interested, an' said he 'd look for a chance for him up to Lowell. It all sounded so well that I kind of begun to think about goin' myself. Mr. Wallis said we'd close the house here, and go an' board through the winter. But he never heard a word from him, and the disappointment was one he never got over. I think of it now different from what I did then. I often used to be kind of disapproving to Mr. Wallis; but there, he used to be always tellin' over his great projects. Somebody told me once that a man by the same name of the one he met while he was to court had got some patents for the very things Mr. Wallis used to be workin' over; but 't was after he died, an' I don't know's 't was in him to ever really set things up so other folks could ha' seen their value. His machines always used to work kind of rickety, but folks used to come from all round to see 'em; they was curiosities if they wa'n't nothin' else, an' gave him a name.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: He was a dreadful notional man. I recollect one time he worked all through the early winter over my churn, an' got it so it would go three quarters of an hour all of itself if you wound it up; an' if you'll believe it, he went an' spent all that time for nothin' when the cow was dry, an' we was with dif- ficulty borrowin' a pint o' milk a day some- wheres in the neighborhood just to get along with.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Now what do you think of such a man as that, Miss Pendexter?
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Why, I don't know but 't was just as good for an invention
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: Then I asked him where it was, one day that spring when I'd got tired to death churnin', an' the butter would n't come in a churn I'd had to borrow, and he 'd gone an' took ours all to pieces to get the works to make some other useless contrivance with. He had no sort of a business turn, but he was well meanin', Mr. Wallis was, an' full o' divertin' talk; they used to call him very good company. I see now that he never had no proper chance. I've always regretted Mr. Wallis.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: I'm sure you always speak well of him. 'T was a pity he had n't got among good business men, who could push his inventions an' do all the business part.
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: I was left very poor an' needy for them next few years. but he never 'd give up but what he should die worth his fifty thousand dollars. I don't see now how I ever did get along them next few years without him; but there, I always managed to keep a pig, an' sister Eliza gave me my potatoes, and I made out somehow. I could dig me a few greens, you know, in spring, and then 't would come strawberry-time, and other berries a-follow- in' on. I was always decent to go to meet- in' till within the last six months, an' then I went in bad weather, when folks wouldn't notice; but 't was a rainy summer, an' I managed to get considerable preachin' after all. My clothes looked proper enough when 't was a wet Sabbath. I often think o' them pinched days now, when I'm left so comfortable by Mr. Bickford.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Yes 'm, you've everything to be thank- ful for. Mr. Bickford was a very personable man
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: Oh, very; there was something about him that was very marked. Strangers would always ask who he was as he come into meetin'. His words counted; he never spoke except he had to. 'T was a relief at first after Mr. Wallis's being so fluent; but Mr. Wallis was splendid company for winter evenings, 't would be eight o'clock before you knew it. I didn't use to listen to it all, but he had a great deal of information. Mr. Bick- ford was dreadful dignified; I used to be sort of meechin' with him along at the first, for fear he'd disapprove of me; but I found out 't wa'n't no need; he was always just that way, an' done everything by rule an' measure. He had n't the mind of my other husbands, but he was a very dignified ap- pearing man; he used 'most always to sleep in the evenin's, Mr. Bickford did.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Them is lovely bo'quets, certain! Why, I could n't tell 'em apart; the flowers are comin' out just right, are n't they?
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: I always seem to forget about your first husband, Mr. Fraley. I've often heard you speak of him, too, but he'd passed away long before I ever knew you.
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: He was but a boy. I thought the world was done for me when he died, but I've often thought since 't was a mercy for him. He come of a very melancholy family, and all his bro- thers an' sisters enjoyed poor health; it might have been his lot. Folks said we was as pretty a couple as ever come into church; we was both dark, with black eyes an' a good deal o' color, you would n't expect it to see me now. Albert was one that held up his head, and looked as if he meant to own the town, an' he had a good word for every- body. I don't know what the years might have brought.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: I expect 't was what they call fallin' in love. he wa'n't nothin' but a boy, an' I wa'n't no- thin' but a girl, but we was dreadful happy. He didn't favor his folks, they all had hay-colored hair and was faded-looking, ex- cept his mother; they was alike, and looked alike, an' set everything by each other. He was just the kind of strong, hearty young man that goes right off if they get a fever. We was just settled on a little farm, an' he'd have done well if he'd had time; ast it was, he left debts. He had a hasty tem- per, that was his great fault, but Albert had a lovely voice to sing; they said there wa'n't no such tenor voice in this part o' the State. I could hear him singin' to himself right out in the field a-ploughin' or hoein', an' he did n't know it half o' the time, no more 'n a common bird would. I don't know's I valued his gift as I ought to, but there was nothin' ever sounded so sweet to me. I ain't one that ever had much fancy, but I knowed Albert had a pretty voice.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: I must hurry now an put these in water. Little Miss Pendexter was so quiet and sympathetic that her hostess felt no more embarrassed than if she had been talking only to herself.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Yes, they do seem to droop some; 'tis a little warm for them here in the sun. but you 'll find they'll all come up if you give them their fill o' water. They'll look very handsome to-morrow; folks 'll notice them from the road. You've arranged them very tasty, Mis' Bickford.
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: They do look pretty, don't they? I want to have them all pretty. You may deem it strange, Abby.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Why, no, Mis' Bickford, I know how 't is with friends, that having one don't keep you from wantin' another; 'tis just like havin' somethin' to eat, and then want- in' somethin' to drink just the same. I ex- pect all friends find their places.
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: I done the best I could while they was alive, and mourned 'em when I lost 'em, an' I feel grateful to be left so comfortable now when all is over. It seems foolish, but I'm still at a loss about that rose.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Perhaps you'll feel sure when you first wake up in the morning. It's a case where I don't deem myself qualified to offer you any advice. But I'll say one thing, see- ing's you've been so friendly spoken and confiding with me. I never was married myself, Mis' Bickford, because it wa'n't so that I could have the one I liked.
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: I suppose he ain't livin', then? Why, I wan't never aware you had met with a disappointment, Abby
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Yes 'm, he's livin'. No 'm, I never have heard that he died.
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: I want to know! Well, I'll tell you this, Abby: you may have regretted your lot, and felt lonesome and hardshipped, but they all have their faults, and a single woman's got her liberty, if she ain't got other blessin's.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: 'T would n't have been my choice to live alone. I feel very thankful for my blessin's, all the same. You've always been a kind neigh- bor, Mis' Bickford.
speaker: Miss Pendexter

utterance: Why can't you stop to tea?
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: What an old fool I be!
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: What, ma'am?
speaker: John

utterance: Aunt Bickford, I may 's well out with it! I've got a piece o' news to tell you, if you won't let on to nobody. I expect you'll laugh, but you know I've set everything by Mary Lizzie Gifford ever since I was a boy. Well, sir!
speaker: John

utterance: Well, sir!
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: I am really pleased. She'll make you a good, smart wife, John. Ain't all the folks pleased, both sides?
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Yes, they be.
speaker: John

utterance: I guess I can make out to do something for you to help along, when the right time comes, I've known what it is to be starting out in life with plenty o' hope. You ain't calculatin' on gettin' married before fall, or be ye?
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Long in the fall, I wish t' we could set up for ourselves right away this summer. I ain't got much ahead, but I can work well as anybody, an' now I'm out o' my time.
speaker: John

utterance: She's a nice, modest, pretty girl. I thought she liked you, John, I saw her over to your mother's, last day I was there. Well, I expect you 'll be happy.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Certain, Thank you, aunt, you 're a real good friend to me; She's coming over to spend the day with the girls, Mother thought of it. You don't get over to see us very often.
speaker: John

utterance: My gracious!
speaker: John

utterance: I'd like to have drove right by the burying-ground. I forgot we wanted to stop.
speaker: John

utterance: Here, you just let me run up with 'em, 'T is hot in the sun to-day, an' you'll mind it risin' the hill. We'll stop as I fetch you back to-night, and you can go up comfortable an' walk the yard after sundown when it's cool, an' stay as long as you 're a mind to. You seem sort of tired, aunt.
speaker: John

utterance: I don't know but what I will let you carry 'em.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: I know who I do hope 's got the right one, There, what a touse I be in! I don't see what I had to go and pick the old rose for, anyway.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: I declare, they did look real handsome, aunt, I set 'em up just as you told me. This one fell out, an' I kept it. I don't know 's you 'll care. I can give it to Lizzie.
speaker: John

utterance: Your choice is easy made,
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: Come, get right in, dear, Well, well! I guess the rose was made for you; it looks very pretty in your coat, John.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: My first husband was just such a tall, straight young man as you be, The flower he first give me was a rose.
speaker: Mrs. Bickford

utterance: I do' know why 't is, but I can't realize nothing about it,
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance: We was just about ready for you, Isr’el, We did n't stop to take anything ourselves this afternoon, and we did n't suppose 't was so you could; an' we thought we'd just make a quiet cup o' tea when we had everything put to rights, and could set down an' enjoy it. Now you draw right up to the table; that's clever; 't will do us all good.
speaker: Mrs. Stevens

utterance: I declare! We could reckon what a sight o' folks there was here this afternoon by the times we had to make new tea, if there wa❜n't no other way. I don't know 's I ever see a larger gathering on such an occasion. Mis' Stevens an' me was trying to count 'em. There was twenty-six wagons hitched in the yard an' lane, so William said, besides all that come afoot; an' a few had driven away before they made the count.
speaker: Mrs. Abby Martin

utterance: I'd no idea of there bein' so many, Well, 't was natural for all who knew her to show respect. I felt much obliged to the folks, and for Elder Wall's excellent remarks.
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance: A number spoke their approval to him in my hearing. He seemed pleased that everything passed off well, I expect he wanted to do the best he could. Everybody knows she was always a good friend to him. I never see anybody that set so by her minister. William was telling of me he'd been very attentive all through her sickness. Poor William! He does mourn, but he behaved very pretty, I thought. He wanted us to tell you that he'd be over to-morrow soon's he could. He wanted dreadful to stop with ye overnight, but we all know what it is to run a milk farm.
speaker: Mrs. Abby Martin

utterance: I'd b'en glad if 't was so he could be here with us to-night, an' his wife with him,
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance: Have you got any notion what it's best to do, sir?
speaker: William Haydon

utterance: I've always been forehanded; I never was caught so unprepared before, 'T has been my way, as you know, to think out things beforehand, but it come to the very last before I could give it up 'bout your mother's gettin' better; an' when I did give up, 't wa'n't so I could think o' anything. An' here's your aunts got their families dependin' on 'em, and wanting to git away soon as may be. I don't know which way to look.
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance: Marilla and I should be thankful if you'd come and stop 'long of us this winter
speaker: William Haydon

utterance: No, no! I ain't goin' to live in the chimbly-corner of another man's house. I ain't but a little past sixty-seven. I've got to stand in my lot an' place. 'T would n't be neither your house nor mine, William, You're a good son; your mother always said you was a good son.
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance: I've gone over everything I wish I could forget all the bothering tricks I played her, 'way back when I was a boy, I declare, I don't know what to do, I miss her so.
speaker: William Haydon

utterance: You was an only child, we done the best we could by ye. She often said you was a good son, and she wa'n't surprised to see ye prosper. An' about Marilly, 'long at the first, when you was courtin' her, 't was only that poor mother thought nobody wa'n't quite good enough for her boy. She come to set everything by Marilly.
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance: Father, I do' know now but I've thought o' the very one!
speaker: William Haydon

utterance: What d' ye mean?
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance: T ain't nobody I feel sure of getting, I had Maria Durrant in my mind - Marilla's cousin. Don't you know, she come and stopped with us six weeks that time. Marilla was so dyin' sick and we hadn't been able to get proper help; and what a providence Maria Durrant was! Mother said one day that she never saw so capable a woman.
speaker: William Haydon

utterance: I don't stand in need of nursin', What's the use, anyway, if you can't get her? I'll contrive to get along somehow. I always have.
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance: Poor mother! how she did love early weather like this!
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance: She'd been getting out to the door twenty times a day, just to have a look. An' how she'd laugh to hear the frogs again! Oh, poor me! poor me!
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance: He feels it much as anybody could, Somehow or 'nother your brother is so methodical and contained, Mis' Martin, that I shouldn't have looked to see him give way like other men.
speaker: Mrs. Stevens

utterance: He never was one that could show his feelin's, I never saw him shed tears before as I know of, but many's the time he has n't been able to control his voice to speak. I wonder what made William hurry off so? His back looked kind o' provoked. They could n't have had no words; whatever it was, they could n't had no words so soon as this; an' William's always respectful.
speaker: Mrs. Abby Martin

utterance: Tain't that either, I've seen sights o' folks in trouble, and I don't know what nor why it is, but they always have to get through with a fractious spell before they can get to work again. They'll hold up an' 'pear splendid, and then something seems to let go, an' everything goes wrong, an' every word plagues 'em. Now Isr'el's my own poor brother, an' you know how I set by him, Mis' Stevens; but I expect we'll have to walk soft to get along with him for a week or two to come. Don't you go an' be too gentle, neither. Treat him just 's you would anyway, and he 'll fetch himself into line the quicker. He always did have days when he wouldn't say nothing to nobody. It does seem's if I ought to be the one to stop longer with him, an' be the most help; but you know how I'm situated. And then your sister's things that 's to be looked over, and you and Marilla is the proper ones.
speaker: Mrs. Abby Martin

utterance: I wish 'twas so you could stop, I feel more acquainted with you than I do with Marilly. But I shall do my best, as I shall want those who come to do for my things when I'm past an' gone. I shall get William to come an' help us; he knows more about his mother's possessions than anybody, I expect. She made a kind of girl of him, for company's sake, when he was little; and he used to sew real pretty before his fingers got too big. Don't you recall one winter when he was house-bound after a run o' scarlet fever? He used to work worsted, and knit some, I believe he did; but he took to grow-in' that spring, and I chanced to ask him to supply me with a couple o' good holders, but I found I'd touched dignity. He was dreadful put out. I suppose he was mos' too manly for me to refer to his needlework. Poor Marthy! how she laughed! I only said that about the holders for the sake o' sayin' somethin', but he remembered it against me more than a year.
speaker: Mrs. Stevens

utterance: Boys is boys, ain't they?
speaker: Mrs. Stevens

utterance: Men is boys, The more you treat 'em like boys, the better they think you use 'em. They always want motherin', an' somebody to come to. I always tell folks I've got five child'n, counting Mr. Martin the youngest. The more bluster they have, the more boys they be. Now Marthy knew that about brother Isr'el, an' she always ruled him by love an' easin' of him down from them high perches he was always settin' upon. Everything was always right with her an' all wrong with him when they was young, but she could always say the right word.
speaker: Mrs. Abby Martin

utterance: She was a good-feelin' woman; she did make him a good wife, if I say it that shouldn't o' my own sister, She was the best o' housekeepers, was Marthy. I never went over so neat a house. I ain't got the gift myself. I can clear up, Mis' Martin, but I can't remain cleared up.
speaker: Mrs. Stevens

utterance: There! we've got to get along a spell without any women folks, my son. I haven't heard of any housekeeper to suit me, but we 'll get along together till I do.
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance: There's a great sight o' things cooked up, sir.
speaker: Thomas

utterance: We'll get along, I won't have you take no liberties, but if we save the time from other things, we can manage just as well as the women. I want you to sweep out good, night an' morning, an' fetch me the wood an' water, an' I'll see to the housework.
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance: There's an old buckle that I lost one day ever so many years ago.
speaker: William Haydon

utterance:
I thought Elder Wall preached an ex-

speaker: William Haydon

Marilla 's worried to death for fear it's on

try to be company for you, as if you thought

speaker: William Haydon

speaker: William Haydon

I want you to ride over with me to sup-

Come; we're goin' to have a hearty supper,

I don't know but I will. We've got on pretty
well-no, we ain't, neither. I ain't com-
fortable, and I can't make nothin' o' that
poor shoat of a boy. I'm buying o' the
baker an' frying a pan o' pork the whole
time, trying to fill him up. I never was
so near out o' pork this time o' year, not
since I went to housekeepin'.
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance:
I heard he'd been tellin' round the
neighborhood that he was about starved. Our folks always
had the name o' being good providers.
speaker: William Haydon

utterance:
How'd your mother use to wash up the
cups an' things to make 'em look decent?
asked Mr. Haydon suddenly; there was

the humility of broken pride in his tone.
I can't seem to find nothin' to do with,
anywhere about the house. I s'posed I
knew where everything was. I expect I've

speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance:
You'll have to ask Marilla. It mortifies me to have you go on
in such a way. Now, father, you would n't
hear to anybody that was named to you, but
if you go on this way much longer you'll
find that any housekeeper's better than

speaker: William Haydon

utterance:
Why, I've only been waiting to hear of
a proper person. My house is in a terrible
state, now I can tell you.
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance: What do you find to laugh at?
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance:
Don't you know I spoke of somebody to
you? I believe 't was the very day after
the funeral. Her name is Maria Durrant.
speaker: William Haydon

utterance:
I remember the person well; an excel-
lent, sensible woman, no flummery, and did
remarkable well in case of sickness at your
house. What of her? You said there was no
chance of getting her, did n't you?
speaker: Israel Haydon

utterance:
I was afraid so; but she's left her bro-
ther's folks now, and come to stop a little

rilla 's very fond of having her cousins come

speaker: William Haydon

utterance:
Anybody 'll do. I tell ye, William, I'm drove to
the wall. I feel to covet a good supper; an'
I'm ashamed to own it, a man o' my prop-

speaker: John Packer

utterance: Looks cold, don't it? I'll be over middle o' the week some time, Mr. Packer.
speaker: the timber-contractor

utterance: There, I don't want to hear no more about the wood-box bein' empty. We're goin' to have a cold night; the air's full of snow, but 't won't fall, not till it moderates.
speaker: John Packer

utterance: 'Come, mother, what you goin' to get me for supper? I'm goin' over to the Centre to the selec'- men's office to-night. They're goin' to have a hearin' about that new piece o' road over in the Dexter neighborhood.
speaker: John Packer

utterance: Poor father! Yes; I'll get you your supper quick's I can. I forgot about to-night. You'll want somethin' warm before you ride 'way over to the Centre, certain;
speaker: Mrs. Packer

utterance: Do put on your big fur coat, won't you, John?
speaker: Mrs. Packer

utterance: I ain't gone yet.
speaker: John Packer

utterance: What are you about there, Lizzie? Why don't you wait till you have a light? Get one for your mother: she can't see over there by the table.
speaker: John Packer

utterance: Have you got a match in your pocket? You know we're all out; I found the last this mornin' in the best room.
speaker: Lizzie Packer

utterance: I won't have you leavin' matches layin' all about the house, mice'll get at 'em, and set us afire. You can make up some lamplighters out of old letters and things; there's a lot o' stuff that might be used up. Seems to me lamplighters is gone out o' fashion; they come in very handy.
speaker: John Packer

utterance: Here, you take these I've got in my pocket, and that 'll remind me to buy some at the store.
speaker: John Packer

utterance: I do hope she won't stay up there in the cold.
speaker: Mrs. Packer

utterance: What's she sulkin' about now?
speaker: John Packer

utterance: Why, when we saw Mr. Ferris out there talkin' with you, we were frightened for fear he was tryin' to persuade you about the big pines. Poor Lizzie got all worked up; she took on and cried like a baby when we saw him go off chucklin' and you stayed out so long. She can't bear the thought o' touchin' 'em. And then when you come in and spoke about the selec'men, we guessed we was all wrong. Perhaps Lizzie feels bad about that now. I own I had hard feelin's toward you myself, John.
speaker: Mrs. Packer

utterance: You see, they 've been such landmarks, John, and our Lizzie's got more feelin' about 'em than anybody. She was always playin' around 'em when she was little; and now there's so much talk about the fishin' folks countin' on 'em to get in by the short channel in bad weather, and she don't want you blamed.
speaker: Mrs. Packer

utterance: You'd ought to set her to work, and learnt her head to save her heels. That's why she ain't no good now playin' out all the time when other girls was made to work. Broke you all down, savin' her.
speaker: John Packer

utterance: John, 'tain't true, is it? Don't you go and do a thing to make everybody hate you. You know what it says in the Bible about movin' a landmark. You'll get your rights; 'tis just as much your right to let the trees stand, and please folks.
speaker: Mrs. Packer

utterance: Come, come, Mary Hannah! Don't work yourself up so. I ain't told you I was goin' to cut 'em, have I? But if I ever do, 't is because I've been twitted into it, an' told they were everybody's trees but mine.
speaker: John Packer

utterance: I ain't goin' out any more this year. I ain't goin' to perish myself for a pinch o' fish like this
speaker: younger man

utterance: Generally it's some warmer than we are gittin' it now, 'way into January. I've got a good chance to go into Otis's shoe- shop; Bill Otis was tellin' me he didn't know but he should go out West to see his uncle's folks, he done well this last sea- son, lobsterin', -an' I can have his bench if I want it. I do' know but I may make up some lobster-pots myself, evenin's an' odd times, and take to lobsterin' another season. I know a few good places that Bill Otis ain't struck; and then the scarcer lob- sters git to be, the more you git for 'em, so now a poor ketch 's 'most better 'n a good one.'
speaker: younger man

utterance: Le' me take the oars.
speaker: Joe Banks

utterance: You hold that sheet light, or these gusts'll have us over. An' don't let that old oar o' yourn range about so. I can't git no hold o' the water.
speaker: other man

utterance: They say the sea holds its heat longer than the land, but I guess summer's about over out here. Come, le' 's say this is the last trip, Joe.
speaker: Chauncey

utterance: We may have it warmer after we git more snow. I'd like to keep on myself until after the first o' the year, same's usual. I've got my reasons, But don't you go out no more, Chauncey.
speaker: Joe Banks

utterance: What you goin' to do about them trees o' Packer's? Old Ferris has laid a bet that he 'll git 'em anyway. I signed the paper they 've got down to Fox'l Berry's store to the Cove. A number has signed it, but I should n't want to be the one to carry it up to Packer. They all want your name, but they've got some feelin' about how you 're situated. Some o' the boys made me promise to speak to you, bein''s we 're keepin' together.
speaker: Chauncey

utterance: You can tell 'em I'll sign it. I don't know what set him out to be so poor-behaved. He's a quick-tempéred man, Packer is, but quick over. I never knew him to keep no such a black temper as this.
speaker: Joe Banks

utterance: They always say that you can't drive a Packer. His mother came o' that old fightin' stock up to Bolton; 't was a different streak from his father's folks they was different-hearted an' all pleasant. Ferris has done the whole mean business. John Packer'd be madder 'n he is now if he knowed how Ferris is makin' a tool of him. He got a little too much aboard long ago's Thanksgivin' Day, and bragged to me an' another fellow when he was balmy how he'd rile up Packer into sellin' them pines, and then he'd double his money on 'em up to Boston; he said there wa'n't no such a tim- ber pine as that big one left in the State that he knows on. Why, 'tis 'most five foot through high 's I can reach.
speaker: Chauncey

utterance: I should miss them old trees; they always make me think of a married couple. They ain't no common growth, be they, Joe? Everybody knows 'em. I bet you if anything happened to one on 'em t'other would go an' die. They say ellums has mates, an' all them big trees.
speaker: Chauncey

utterance: She'll make it now, herself, if you'll just keep her straight, Chauncey; no, 't wa'n't nothin' but a flaw, was it? Guess I'd better help ye;
speaker: Joe Banks

utterance: We're right over one o' my best lobster rocks. I'm satisfied not to be no further out; it's beginnin' to snow; see them big flakes a-comin'? I'll tell the boys about your signin' the paper; I do' know's you'd better resk it, either.
speaker: Chauncey

utterance: Why not? I suppose you refer to me an' Lizzie Packer; but she would n't think no more o' me for leavin' my name off a proper neigh- borhood paper, nor her father, neither. You git them two pines let alone, and I'll take care o' Lizzie. I've got all the other boats and men to think of besides me, an' I've got some pride anyway. I ain't goin' to have Bolton folks an' all on 'em down to the Centre twittin' us, nor twittin' Packer; he'll turn sour toward everybody the minute he does it. I know Packer; he's rough and ugly, but he ain't the worst man in town by a good sight. Anybody 'd be all worked up to go through so much talk, and I'm kind o' 'fraid this minute his word 's passed to Ferris to have them trees down. But you show him the petition; 't will be kind of formal, and if that don't do no good, I do' know what will. There you git the sail in while I hold her stiddy, Chauncey.
speaker: Joe Banks

utterance: I can haul her out and fix her up for winter when I git ashore. I've been distressed to think it wa'n't done before. I expect she's got some little ice in her now, there where she lays just under the edge of Joe Banks's fish-house. I spoke to Joe, but he said she'd do till I could git down. No; I'll turn her over, and make her snug for winter, and git a small boat o' Joe. I ain't goin' out a great ways: just so's I can git a cod or two. I always begin to think of a piece o' new fish quick's these mild days come; feels like the Janooary thaw.
speaker: John Packer

utterance: 'T would be a good day for you to ride over to Bolton, too. But I'd like to go with you when you go there, an' I've got business here to-day. I've put the kettle on some time ago to do a little colorin'. We can go to Bolton some day next week.
speaker: Mrs. Packer

utterance: I've got to be here next week.
speaker: Packer

utterance: You put me up a bite o' somethin' hearty, mother. I sha'n't git in till along in the afternoon.
speaker: John Packer

utterance: Ain't you feelin' all right, father?
speaker: Lizzie Packer

utterance: I be. I feel like a day out fishin'. I hope Joe won't git the start o' me. You seen his small boat go out?
speaker: John Packer

utterance: Don't you want to come, Joe?
speaker: Mr. Packer

utterance: What's he puttin' in so for?
speaker: Joe Banks

utterance: He's pullin' at them oars as if the devil was after him. He could n't ha' heard o' that petition they're gettin' up from none of the fish he's hauled in; 't will 'bout set him crazy, but I was bound I'd sign it with the rest. The old dory's jumpin' right out of water every stroke he pulls.'
speaker: Joe Banks

utterance: Lizzie's there she 'll hold 'em back till I come. Oh, Lord! what a fool! I ain't goin' to have them trees murdered;
speaker: Packer

utterance: Here they all
speaker: youngest

utterance: come,
speaker: somebody

utterance: Here they come! I guess you'd better go in, Joe; they 'll want to have lights ready.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: She'll have a fire all laid for him in the fore room, that's all we want. She'll be expectin' you, Joe: go in now, and they'll think nothin' of it, bein' Saturday night. Just you hurry, so they'll have time to light up.
speaker: the young man

utterance: Stop and have some talk with father, He's all worked up, thinking nobody 'll respect him, an' all that. Tell him you 're glad he beat.
speaker: Lizzie Packer

utterance: What's all that noise?
speaker: John Packer

utterance: What's all that noise, Joe?
speaker: John Packer

utterance: I guess the neighbors mean to give you a little party to-night, sir, I see six or eight sleighs comin' along the road. They've all heard about it; some o' 275 the boys that was here with the riggin' went down to the store last night, and they was all tellin' how you stood right up to Ferris like a king, an' drove him. You see, they 're all gratified on account of your having you put a stop to Ferris's tricks about them pines,
speaker: Joe Banks

utterance: Come, sir, give us a taste before we go up; it's master hot up there,
speaker: Chauncey

utterance: Whatever become o' that petition?
speaker: Chauncey

utterance: Wish ye merry Christmas!
speaker: Chauncey

utterance: Hold that light nearer, Come, Joe, I ain't goin' to hear no more o' that nonsense about me beatin' off old Ferris.
speaker: John Packer

utterance: Land! there's the fiddle, Le''s hurry up;
speaker: Chauncey

utterance: There must be somebody wanting to speak with me on an errand,
speaker: Maria Lunn

utterance: Oh, walk right in, Cap'n Crowe!
speaker: Maria Lunn

utterance: I just looked in to report about our little matter of business. I've got the estimates with me, but 't will do just as well another time,
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: I could buy him an' sell him twice over,
speaker: Captain Shaw

utterance: Oh, my, yes! T ain't as if 't was any kind o' consequence, you know; not but what I'm just as much obliged.
speaker: Maria Lunn

utterance: I come by your house just now, Your young folks seemed to be havin' a great time. Well, I like to see young folks happy. They gen- erally be, 't is we old ones have the worst of it, soon as they begin to want to have everything their way.
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: I don't allow no trouble for'ard when I'm on deck, I like to give 'em their liberty. To-night they were bound on some sort of a racket -they got some other young folks in; but gen'ally they do pretty well. I'm goin' to take my oldest boy right into the office, first o' January - put him right to business. I need more help; I've got too much now for me an' Decket to handle, though Decket's a good accountant.
speaker: Captain Shaw

utterance: Well, I'm glad I'm out of it, I don't want the bother o' business. I don't need to slave.
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: No; you should n't have too much to carry at your time o' life,
speaker: Captain Shaw

utterance: What's been goin' on down street to- day? I haven't had occasion to go out, and I don't have anybody to bring me the news, as I used to.
speaker: Maria Lunn

utterance: Here's Cap'n Shaw makin' me out to be old enough to be his grandfather, Now, everybody knows I ain't but five years the oldest. Shaw, you must n't be settin' up for a young dandy. I've had a good deal more sea ser- vice than you. I believe you never went out on a long voyage round the Cape or the like o' that; those long voyages count a man two years to one, if they 're hard passages.
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: No; I only made some few trips; the rest you might call coastin', I come to the conclusion I'd better stop ashore. If I could ever have found me a smart, dependable crew, I might have fol- lowed the sea longer than I did.
speaker: Captain Shaw

utterance: I thought I heard somebody knocking a few minutes ago. Here, now, I'm goin' to the door for you, Mis' Lunn; there may be a tramp or somethin'.
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: Oh, no, I guess it's only somebody to speak about the washing. Mrs. Dimmett's been sick
speaker: Maria Lunn

utterance: I don't know but what I will, after all, step in an' set down for just a minute, I'll just wash my hands here at the sink, if you'll let me, same's I did the other day. I should n't have bothered you so late about a mere fish, but they was such prime mackerel, an' I thought like's not one of 'em would make you a breakfast.
speaker: Captain Witherspoon

utterance: You're always very considerate, Walk right in, Cap'n Witherspoon, when you get ready. You'll find some o' your friends. 'Tis The Cap'n,' gentlemen,
speaker: Maria Lunn

utterance: What's the news? Anything heard from the new minister yet, Crowe? I suppose, though, the ladies are likely to hear of those matters first.
speaker: Captain Witherspoon

utterance: Yes, sir, I was told, just before tea, that he had written to Deacon Torby that he felt moved to accept the call.
speaker: Maria Lunn

utterance: I've seen his plaguy logs; and what she can find, I don't see. There ain't nothin' to a page but his figures, and what men were sick, and how the seas run, an' So ends the day.'
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: Everybody's after her; I've got to look sharp, I guess I'd better give her to understand what I'm worth.
speaker: Captain Shaw

utterance: Both o' them old sea-dogs is steerin' for the same port as I be. I'll cut 'em out, if only for the name of it see if I don't!
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: I care a world more about poor Maria than anybody else does,
speaker: Captain Witherspoon

utterance: Looks lonesomer than ever, don't it? I vow it's a shame to see such a harbor as this, an' think o' all the back country, an' how things were goin' on here in our young days.
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: 'Tis sad, sir, sad. They've taken the wrong course for the country's good - some o' those folks in Washington. When the worst of 'em have stuffed their own pockets as full as they can get, p'r'aps they'll see what else can be done, and all catch hold together and shore up the shipping int'rists. I see every night, when I go after my paper, the whole sidewalk full o' louts that ought to be pushed off to sea with a good smart master; they're going to the devil ashore, sir. Every way you can look at it, shippin''s a loss to us.
speaker: Captain Witherspoon

utterance: It used to cost but a ninepence to get a bar'l from Boston by sea, and now it costs twenty-five cents by the railroad, sir.
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: You an' I never expected to see Long- port harbor look like this. I don't know's I ever saw things look so poor along these wharves as they do to-day. I've seen six or seven large vessels at a time waitin' out in the stream there until they could get up to the wharves. You could stand ashore an' hear their masters rippin' an' swearin' aboard, an' fur's you could see from here, either way, the masts and riggin' looked like the woods in winter-time. There used to be somethin' doin' in this place when we was young men, Cap'n Witherspoon.
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: I feel it as much as anybody. Looks to me very much as if there was a vessel comin' up, down there over Dimmett's P'int; she may only be runnin' in closer 'n usual on this light sou'easterly breeze; yes, I s'pose that's all. What do you make her out to be, sir?
speaker: Captain Witherspoon

utterance: She ain't comin' in; she's only one o' them great schooners runnin' west'ard. I'd as soon put to sea under a Monday's clothes-line, for my part.
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: Yes; give me a brig, sir, a good able brig. I don't care if she's a little chunky, neither. I'd make more money out of her than out o' any o' these gre't new-fangled things. I'd as soon try to sail a whole lumber-yard to good advantage. Gi' me an old-fashioned house an' an old-style vessel; there was some plan an' reason to 'em. Now that new house of Asa Shaw's he 's put so much money in looks as if a nor'west wind took an' hove it together. Shaw's just the man to call for one o' them schooners we just spoke of.
speaker: Captain Witherspoon

utterance: No, sir, I don't put any confidence in the story at all.
speaker: Captain Witherspoon

utterance: It might be of mutual advantage.
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: The new minister's a dozen years younger than she; must be all o' that. I called him quite a young-lookin' man when he preached for us as a candidate. Sing'lar he should n't be a married man. Generally they be.
speaker: Captain Witherspoon

utterance: You ain't the right one to make reflec- tions. I used to think you was a great beau among the ladies, Witherspoon.
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: I never expected to die a single man.
speaker: Captain Witherspoon

utterance: You're gettin' along in years. You're gettin' to where it's dangerous; a good-hearted elderly man 's liable to be snapped up by somebody he don't want. They say an old man ought to be married, but he should n't get married. I don't know but it's so.
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: I've put away my thoughts o' youth long since. Though I ain't so old, sir, but what I've got some years before me yet, unless I meet with accident; an' I'm so situated that I never yet had to take anybody that I didn't want. But I do often feel that there's somethin' to be said for the affections, an' I get to feelin' lonesome winter nights, thinkin' that age is before me, an' if I should get hove on to a sick an' dyin' bed
speaker: Captain Witherspoon

utterance: Come, come! ain't we gettin' into the doldrums, Crowe? I'll just step in an' close up the warehouse; it must be time to make for supper.
speaker: Captain Witherspoon

utterance: May I take the liberty? I saw you settin' by the window this wet day.
speaker: Captain Shaw

utterance: Walk right in, sir; do!
speaker: Mrs. Lunn

utterance: I'm glad, ma'am, to find you alone. I have long had it in mind to speak with you on a matter of interest to us both.
speaker: Captain Shaw

utterance: It relates to the future. I make no doubt you have seen what my feelin's have been this good while. I can offer you a good home, and I shall want you to have your liberty.
speaker: Captain Shaw

utterance: I enjoy a good home and my liberty now.
speaker: Mrs. Lunn

utterance: I mean liberty to use my means, and to have plenty to do with, so as to make you feel comfortable. Mis' Lunn, I'm a straight- forward business man, and I intend busi- ness now. I don't know any of your flow- ery ways of sayin' things, but there ain't anybody in Longport I'd like better to see at the head of my house. You and I ain't young, but we
speaker: Captain Shaw

utterance: Don't say a word, sir. You can get you just as good housekeepers as I am. I don't feel to change my situation just at present, sir.
speaker: Mrs. Lunn

utterance: Is that final? Come now, Maria! I'm a good-hearted man, I'm worth over forty thousand dollars, and I'll make you a good husband, I promise. Here's the minister on your hands, I know. I did feel all ashore when I found you'd promised to take him in. I tried to get a chance to speak with you before you went off, but when I come home from New York 't was the first news I heard. I don't deem it best for you; you can't make nothin' out o' one boarder, anyway. I tried it once myself.
speaker: Captain Shaw

utterance: Excuse me, Mr. Shaw, I know my own business best. You have had my answer, sir. Not but what I feel obliged to you for payin' me the compliment.
speaker: Mrs. Lunn

utterance: Oh, Mis' Lunn, I saw some elegant mack- erel brought ashore, blown up from the south'ard, I expect, though so late in the season; and I recalled that you once found some acceptable. I thought 't would help you out.
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: I'm obliged to you, Captain Crowe, and to think of your bringin' 'em yourself this drenchin' day! I take it very neighborly, sir.
speaker: Mrs. Lunn

utterance: Was that the wind sprung up so quick?
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: I expect it was Captain Shaw, just leavin'. He's always full o' business, ain't he? No won- der those children of his are without man- ners.
speaker: Mrs. Lunn

utterance: Maria, I s'pose you know what I'm think- in' of?
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: I don't, Cap'n Crowe, I know it ain't polite to talk about your goin' when you've just come in; but when you do go, I've got something I want to send over to your sister Eliza.
speaker: Mrs. Lunn

utterance: What are you payin' now for potatoes, sir?
speaker: Mrs. Lunn

utterance: Sixty cents a bushel for the last, ma'am, I wish you'd hear to me, Maria, I wish
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: Now don't, cap'n, I've made other arrange- ments. At any rate, at any rate, I deem it best to wait until the late potatoes come into market; they seem to keep better.
speaker: Mrs. Lunn

utterance: Oh! them ministers, them ministers!
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: I wish you'd step in just one minute, sir, if it's perfectly convenient.
speaker: Mrs. Lunn

utterance: I'm 'most too wet to come into a lady's parlor. Command me, Mrs. Lunn, if there's any way I can serve you. I expect to go down street again this evening.
speaker: Captain Witherspoon

utterance: Do you think you'd better, sir?
speaker: Mrs. Lunn

utterance: I have had some business fall to me, you see, Cap'n, and I feel as if I'd better ask your advice. My late cousin, Mrs. Hicks, has left me all her property. The amount is very unexpected; I never looked for more than a small remembrance. There will have to be steps taken.
speaker: Mrs. Lunn

utterance: Command me, madam.
speaker: Captain Witherspoon

utterance: Maria, I dare say it's no time to say the word just now, but if you could feel toward me
speaker: Captain Witherspoon

utterance: T will be pleasant for me to have company again. I think 't is better for a person. I guess Mr. Farley's situation is goin' to please him, too, I feel as if I'd done it all for the best.
speaker: Mrs. Lunn

utterance: T is about time now for the Cap'n to go down town after his newspaper.
speaker: Mrs. Lunn

utterance: I've been a very fortunate man, sir. My own property has looked up a good deal since I was married, what with that piece of land I sold for the new hotel, and other things that have come to bear this wharf property, for instance. I shall have to lay out con- siderable for new plank, but I'm able to do it.
speaker: Captain Witherspoon

utterance: Yes, sir; things have started up in Longport a good deal this spring; but it never is goin' to be what it was once. Don't you think, Cap- tain Witherspoon, that you ought to consider the mat- ter of re-shinglin' your house? You'll have to engage men now, anyway, to do your plankin'. I know of some extra cedar shin- gles that were landed yesterday from some- wheres up river. Or was Mis' Witherspoon a little over-anxious last season?
speaker: Captain Crowe

utterance: I think, with proper attention, sir, that the present shingles may last us a number of years yet.
speaker: Captain Witherspoon
